revision.comment: [[Wikipedia:OABOT|Open access bot]]: add pmc identifier to citation with #oabot.
revision.text:
{{Thermoreg}} A '''eurytherm''' is an [[organism]], often an [[endotherm]], that can function at a wide range of ambient temperatures.{{cite journal|last1=Giomi|first1=Folco|last2=Pörtner|first2=Hans-Otto|date=15 May 2013|title=A role for haemolymph oxygen capacity in heat tolerance of eurythermal crabs|url=https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fphys.2013.00110/full|journal=Frontiers in Physiology|doi=10.3389/fphys.2013.00110}} To be considered a eurytherm, all stages of an organism's [[Biological life cycle|life cycle]] must be considered, including [[Juvenile (organism)|juvenile]] and [[larva]]l stages.{{Cite journal|last=Dybern|first=Bernt I.|date=1965|title=The Life Cycle of Ciona intestinalis (L.) f. typica in Relation to the Environmental Temperature|jstor=3564870|journal=Oikos|volume=16|issue=1/2|pages=109–131|doi=10.2307/3564870}} These wide ranges of tolerable temperatures are directly derived from the tolerance of a given eurythermal organism's [[protein]]s.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/34472042|title=Animals and temperature : phenotypic and evolutionary adaptation|last=|first=|date=1996|publisher=Cambridge University Press|others=Johnston, Ian A., Bennett, Albert F.|year=|isbn=0521496586|location=Cambridge [England]|pages=54|oclc=34472042}} Extreme examples of eurytherms include Tardigrades (''[[Tardigrade|Tardigrada]]''), the desert pupfish ([[Desert pupfish|''Cyprinodon macularis'']]), and green crabs (''[[Carcinus maenas]]''), however, nearly all [[mammal]]s, including [[human]]s, are considered eurytherms.{{Cite journal|last=Lowe|first=Charles H.|last2=Heath|first2=Wallace G.|date=1969|title=Behavioral and Physiological Responses to Temperature in the Desert Pupfish Cyprinodon macularius|url=https://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/abs/10.1086/physzool.42.1.30152465?journalCode=physzool|journal=Physiological Zoology|language=en|volume=42|issue=1|pages=53–59|doi=10.1086/physzool.42.1.30152465|issn=0031-935X|via=}}{{Citation|last=Horikawa|first=Daiki D.|title=Survival of Tardigrades in Extreme Environments: A Model Animal for Astrobiology|date=2011-08-23|url=https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-94-007-1896-8_12|work=Cellular Origin, Life in Extreme Habitats and Astrobiology|pages=205–217|publisher=Springer Netherlands|language=en|doi=10.1007/978-94-007-1896-8_12|isbn=9789400718951|accessdate=2018-06-07}}{{Cite journal|last=Le Roux|first=P. J.|last2=Branch|first2=G. M.|last3=Joska|first3=M. A. P.|date=1990|title=On the distribution, diet and possible impact of the invasive European shore crab Carcinus maenas (L.) along the South African coast.|url=https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.2989/025776190784378835|journal=South African Journal of Marine Science|volume=9|pages=|via=}} Eurythermy can be an evolutionary advantage: adaptations to cold temperatures, called cold-eurythemy, are seen as essential for the survival of species during [[ice age]]s.{{Cite journal|last=Portner|first=Hans O.|date=2004|title=Climate Variability and the Energetic Pathways of Evolution: The Origin of Endothermy in Mammals and Birds on JSTOR|jstor=10.1086/423742|journal=Physiological and Biochemical Zoology: Ecological and Evolutionary Approaches,|volume=77|pages=959–981|doi=10.1086/423742.pdf}} In addition, the ability to survive in a wide range of temperatures increases a species' ability to inhabit other areas, an advantage for [[natural selection]]. Eurythermy is an aspect of thermoregulation in organisms. It is in contrast with the idea of [[stenothermic]] organisms, which can only operate within a relatively narrow range of ambient temperatures.Hill R, Wyse G, Anderson A. Animal Physiology. 2004. Sinaur Associates, Inc. Through a wide variety of thermal coping mechanisms, eurythermic organisms can either provide or expel heat for themselves in order to survive in cold or hot, respectively, or otherwise prepare themselves for extreme temperatures. Certain species of eurytherm have been shown to have unique protein synthesis processes that differentiate them from relatively stenothermic, but otherwise similar, species. [[File:Cañón Miles, Yukón, Canadá, 2017-08-26, DD 130-132 PAN.jpg|alt=Picture of Canon Miles, Yukon, Canada|thumb|272x272px|A boreal forest in Canada. This forest would likely house deciduous conifers.]] == Examples == * Tardigrades, known for their ability to survive in nearly any [[Environment (biophysical)|environment]], are extreme examples of eurytherms. Certain species of tardigrade, including ''Mi. tardigradum'', are able to withstand and survive temperatures ranging from –273 °C (near [[absolute zero]]) to 150 °C in their [[Anhydrobiosis|anhydrobiotic]] state.
  • The desert pupfish, a rare bony fish that occupies places like the [[Colorado River Delta]] in [[Baja California]], small ponds in [[Sonora|Sonora, Mexico]], and drainage sites near the [[Salton Sea]] in [[California]], can function in waters ranging from 8º to 42 °C.
  • The green crab is a common species of [[Littoral zone|littoral]] crab with a range that extends from [[Iceland]] and Central [[Norway]] in the north to [[South Africa]] and [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria, Australia]] in the south, including more temperate regions like [[Maghreb|Northwest Africa]] in between. The green crab has been shown to survive in waters at least as cold as 8 °C, and at least as warm as 35 °C.
  • [[Subarctic climate|Boreal]] [[deciduous]] [[Pinophyta|conifers]] (genus ''[[Larch|Larix]]'') are the primary plants occupying the [[Taiga|boreal forests]] of [[Siberia]] and North America. Although they are conifers, they are deciduous, and therefore lose their needles in Autumn. Species like the black spruce, or tamarak (''[[Larix laricina]]'') occupy wide swaths of land ranging from [[Indiana]] in the south, well into the arctic circle in Northern [[Alaska]], [[Canada]], and Siberia in the north.{{Citation|last=Service|first=Elbert L. Little, Jr , of the U. S. Department of Agriculture, Forest|title=English: Natural distribution map for Larix laricina (tamarack)|date=1971|url=https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Larix_laricina_range_map_3.png|accessdate=2018-06-08}} It has been shown that the black spruce can endure temperatures as cold as –85°, and at least as warm as 20 °C.
  • Killer whales (''[[Killer whale|Orcinus Orca]]'') are found at nearly every latitude on earth.{{Citation|title=English: Range of killer whale (Orcinus orca).|date=2011-11-12|url=https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Cypron-Range_Orcinus_orca.svg|accessdate=2018-06-08}} They are able to withstand water temperatures ranging from 0° to 30-35 °C.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/316226747|title=Encyclopedia of marine mammals|last=|first=|date=2009|publisher=Elsevier/Academic Press|others=Perrin, William F., Würsig, Bernd G., Thewissen, J. G. M.|year=|isbn=9780080919935|edition= 2nd|location=Amsterdam|pages=|chapter=Killer Whale: Orcinus orca|oclc=316226747}} Killer whales are deemed a [[Cosmopolitan distribution|cosmopolitan species]], along with the osprey (''[[Osprey|Pandion haliaetus]]'') and the house sparrow (''[[House sparrow|Passer domesticus]]'').{{Cite journal|last=Greene|first=Erick|date=September 1987|title=Individuals in an osprey colony discriminate between high and low quality information|url=https://www.nature.com/articles/329239a0|journal=Nature|language=En|volume=329|issue=6136|pages=239–241|doi=10.1038/329239a0|issn=0028-0836}}{{Cite journal|date=2010-02-26|title=Toxoplasma gondii and Neospora caninum in sparrows (Passer domesticus) in the Northeast of Brazil|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0304401709006232|journal=Veterinary Parasitology|language=en|volume=168|issue=1-2|pages=121–124|doi=10.1016/j.vetpar.2009.09.055|issn=0304-4017}}
[[File:Cypron-Range_Orcinus_orca.svg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Cypron-Range_Orcinus_orca.svg|alt=The range distribution of the killer whale, which extends from Antarctica in the south to the arctic circle in the north.|thumb|The distribution of the killer whale (''Orcinus Orca'') shown in blue. This cosmopolitan species occupies nearly every area of the [[World Ocean|world ocean]].]] == Advantages over Stenotherms == It is thought that adaptations to cold temperatures (cold-eurythermy) in animals, despite the high cost of [[Adaptation|functional adaptation]], has allowed for mobility and agility. This cold eurythermy is also viewed as a near necessity for survival of the evolutionary crises, including ice ages, that occur with relative frequency over the [[Timeline of the evolutionary history of life|evolutionary timescale]]. Due to its ability to provide the excess energy and aerobic scope required for [[endotherm]]y, eurythermy is considered to be the "missing link" between [[ectotherm]]y and endothermy.{{Cite journal|last=Portner|first=Hans O.|date=2004|title=Climate Variability and the Energetic Pathways of Evolution: The Origin of Endothermy in Mammals and Birds on JSTOR|jstor=10.1086/423742|journal=Physiological and Biochemical Zoology: Ecological and Evolutionary Approaches,|volume=77|pages=959–981|doi=10.1086/423742.pdf}} The green crab's success demonstrates one example of eurythermic advantage. Although [[invasive species]] are typically considered to be detrimental to the environment in which they are introduced, and even considered to be a leading cause of animal [[extinction]]s,{{Cite journal|last=Clavero|first=Miguel|last2=Garcia-Berthou|first2=Emili|date=2005|title=Invasive species are a leading cause of animal extinctions|url=https://doi.org/10.1016/j.tree.2005.01.003|journal=Trends in Ecology & Evolution|volume=20|issue=3|pages=110–110|doi=10.1016/j.tree.2005.01.003|issn=0169-5347|via=}} the ability of an animal to thrive in various environmental conditions is a form of [[Fitness (biology)|evolutionary fitness]], and therefore is typically a characteristic of successful species. A species' relative eurythermality is one of the main factors in its ability to survive in different conditions. One example of eurythermic advantage can be seen in the failure of many of the world's [[Coral reef|coral reefs.]] Most species of coral are considered to be stenothermic.{{Cite journal|date=2013-01-15|title=Ecospace variability along a carbonate platform at the northern boundary of the Miocene reef belt (Upper Langhian, Austria)|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0031018212006979|journal=Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology|language=en|volume=370|pages=232–246|doi=10.1016/j.palaeo.2012.12.015|issn=0031-0182}} The worldwide increase in oceanic temperatures has caused many coral reefs to begin bleaching and dying because the coral have begun to expel the [[zooxanthellae]] algae that live in their tissues and provide them with their food and color.{{Cite journal|last=Glynn|first=P. W.|last2=D'Croz|first2=L.|date=April 1990|title=Experimental evidence for high temperature stress as the cause of El Nino-coincident coral mortality|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/BF00265009|journal=Coral Reefs|volume=8|issue=4|pages=181–191|doi=10.1007/bf00265009|issn=0722-4028|via=}}{{Cite news|url=https://news.nationalgeographic.com/2016/03/160321-coral-bleaching-great-barrier-reef-climate-change/|title=Corals Are Dying on the Great Barrier Reef|date=2016-03-21|access-date=2018-06-08}} This bleaching has resulted in a 50% mortality rate in observed corals in the waters off of [[Cape York Peninsula|Cape York]] in Northeastern [[Australia]], and a 12% bleaching rate in observed reefs throughout the world.{{Cite web|url=https://blog.nationalgeographic.org/2015/10/29/global-coral-bleaching-event-puts-reefs-at-risk/|title=Global Coral Bleaching Event puts Reefs at Risk – National Geographic Blog|website=blog.nationalgeographic.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-06-08}} Although regulators, especially endotherms, expend a significantly higher proportion of energy per unit of mass, the advantages of endothermy, particularly [[Endogeny (biology)|endogenous]] thermogenesis, have proven significant enough for [[Natural selection|selection]].{{Cite journal|last=Anderson|first=Kristina J.|last2=Jetz|first2=Walter|date=2005-02-25|title=The broad-scale ecology of energy expenditure of endotherms|url=https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1111/j.1461-0248.2005.00723.x|journal=Ecology Letters|language=en|volume=8|issue=3|pages=310–318|doi=10.1111/j.1461-0248.2005.00723.x|issn=1461-023X}} ==Thermal Coping Mechanisms== The ability to maintain [[homeostasis]] at varying temperatures is the most important characteristic in defining an endothermic eurytherm, whereas other, thermoconforming eurytherms like tardigrades are simply able to endure significant shifts in their internal body temperature that occur with ambient temperature changes.{{Cite journal|last=Ramloy|first=UB|date=2000|title=Aspects of natural cold tolerance in ectothermic animals.|url=|journal=Human Reproduction|volume=15|pages=26–46|via=}} Eurythermic animals can be either conformers or regulators, meaning that their internal physiology can either vary with the external environment or maintain consistency regardless of the external environment, respectively. It is important to note that endotherms do not solely rely on internal thermogenesis for all parts of homeostasis or comfort; in fact, in many ways, they are equally as reliant upon behavior to regulate body temperature as ectotherms are.{{Citation|last=Harshaw|first=Christopher|title=Thermoregulation, Energetics, and Behavior.|date=2017-01-16|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/307453574_Thermoregulation_Energetics_and_Behavior|last2=Blumberg|last3=Alberts|first2=Mark|first3=Jeffrey|accessdate=2018-06-08}} Reptiles are ectotherms, and therefore rely upon [[Thermotaxis|positive thermotaxis]], basking (heliothermy), burrowing, and crowding with members of their species in order to regulate their body temperature within a narrow range and even to produce fevers to fight infection. Similarly, humans rely upon clothing, housing, air conditioning, and drinking to achieve the same goals, although humans are not considered indicative of endotherms on the whole.{{Cite journal|date=2003-02-01|title=The energetic cost of locomotion: humans and primates compared to generalized endotherms|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0047248402002099|journal=Journal of Human Evolution|language=en|volume=44|issue=2|pages=255–262|doi=10.1016/S0047-2484(02)00209-9|issn=0047-2484}} [[File:Kleiner_Taschenkrebs_(Carcinus_maenas).jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Kleiner_Taschenkrebs_(Carcinus_maenas).jpg|alt=Antique illustration of a green shore crab (Carcinus maenas).|thumb|The green crab is an exceedingly common species of shore crab. Considered an invasive species, the green crab's ability to function in a wide range of water and air temperatures allows it to vary widely in its range.]] The sustained supply of oxygen to body tissues determines the body temperature range of an organism. Eurytherms that live in environments with large temperature changes adapt to higher temperatures through a variety of methods. In green crabs, the process of initial warming results in an increase of oxygen consumption and heart rate, accompanied by a decrease in [[stroke volume]] and [[haemolymph]] oxygen [[partial pressure]]. As this warming continues, dissolved oxygen levels decrease below the threshold for full haemocyanin [[oxygen saturation]]. This heating then progressively releases [[haemocyanin]]-bound oxygen, saving energy in oxygen transport and resulting in an associated leveling off of [[metabolic rate]]. Key to maintaining homeostasis, individual thermoregulation is the ability to maintain internal body temperature in humans, the most recognizable eurytherm. In humans, deep-body temperature is regulated by [[Human skin|cutaneous]] [[Hemodynamics|blood flow]], which maintains this temperature despite changes in the external environment.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/895500922|title=Human Physiology|last=Ira|first=Stuart Fox|publisher=|year=2016|isbn=9780077836375|edition= 14th|location=New York, NY|pages=450–492|chapter=Cardiac Output, Blood Flow, and Blood Pressure|oclc=895500922}} ''[[Homo sapiens|Homo Sapiens]]''' ability to survive in different ambient temperatures is a key factor in the species success, and one cited reason for why ''Homo sapiens'' eventually outcompeted Neanderthals (''[[Homo neandertalensis|Homo neanderthalensis]]).''{{Cite journal|last=Potts|first=Richard|date=1998|title=Environmental Hypotheses of Hominin Evolution|url=|journal=American Journal of Physical Anthropology|volume=107|pages=93–136|via=}} Humans have two major forms of [[thermogenesis]]. The first is [[shivering]], in which a [[warm-blooded]] creature produces involuntary contraction of [[skeletal muscle]] in order to produce heat.{{Cite web|url=https://opentextbc.ca/anatomyandphysiology/chapter/4-4-muscle-tissue-and-motion/|title=4.4 Muscle Tissue and Motion – Anatomy and Physiology|website=opentextbc.ca|language=en-US|access-date=2018-06-08}} In addition, shivering also signals the body to produce [[FNDC5|irisin]], a hormone that has been shown to convert [[White adipose tissue|white fat]] to [[Brown adipose tissue|brown fat]], which is used in non-shivering thermogenesis, the second type of human thermogensis.{{Cite news|url=https://www.scientificamerican.com/podcast/episode/shivering-activates-brown-fat/|title=Shivering Activates Fat to Keep You Warm|last=Intagliata|first=Christopher|work=Scientific American|access-date=2018-06-08|language=en}} Non-shivering thermogenesis occurs in the brown fat, which contains the [[uncoupling protein]] [[thermogenin]]. This protein decreases the proton gradient generated in [[oxidative phosphorylation]] during the synthesis of [[Adenosine triphosphate|ATP]], uncoupling the [[Electron transport chain|electron transport]] in the [[mitochondrion]] from the production of chemical energy (ATP). This creation of a gradient across the [[Cell membrane|mitochondrial membrane]] causes energy to be lost as heat.{{Cite news|url=https://www.britannica.com/science/brown-adipose-tissue#ref1182545|title=Brown adipose tissue {{!}} anatomy|work=Encyclopedia Britannica|access-date=2018-06-08|language=en}} On the other hand, humans have only one method of cooling themselves, biologically speaking: [[Perspiration|sweat]] [[evaporation]]. Cutaneous [[Merocrine|eccrine]] sweat glands produce sweat, which is made up of mostly water with a small amount of ions. Evaporation of this sweat helps to cool the blood beneath the skin, resulting in a cooling of deep-body temperature. [[File:Hypsibiusdujardini.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Hypsibiusdujardini.jpg|alt=A tardigrade and a tardigrade curled up in its tun stage.|thumb|A Tardigrade is able to enter an anhydrobiotic stage, often called a tun, in order to increase the range of temperatures that it can withstand.]] While some organisms are eurythermic due to their ability to regulate internal body temperature, like humans, others have wildly different methods of extreme temperature tolerance. Tardigrades are able to enter an anhydrobiotic state, often called a tun, in order to both prevent [[desiccation]] and endure extreme temperatures. In this state, tardigrades decrease their bodily water to about 1–3% wt./wt. Although this state allows certain tardigrades to endure temperatures at the extremes of –273° and 150 °C at the extremes, tardigrades in their hydrated state are able to withstand temperatures as low as –196 °C. This displayed [[Extremophile|extremotolerance]] has led scientists to speculate that tardigrades could theoretically survive on [[Mars]], where temperatures regularly fluctuate between –123° and 25 °C, as well as even possibly the near absolute zero of [[Outer space|interplanetary space]]. The tardigrade's ability to withstand extremely cold temperatures as a tun is a form of [[cryptobiosis]] called cryobiosis. Although the high temperature endurance of tardigrades has been significantly less studied, their cryobiotic response to low temperatures has been well-documented.{{Cite journal|date=2016-02-01|title=Recovery and reproduction of an Antarctic tardigrade retrieved from a moss sample frozen for over 30 years|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0011224015300134|journal=Cryobiology|language=en|volume=72|issue=1|pages=78–81|doi=10.1016/j.cryobiol.2015.12.003|issn=0011-2240}}{{Cite journal|last=Møbjerg|first=N.|last2=Halberg|first2=K. A.|last3=Jørgensen|first3=A.|last4=Persson|first4=D.|last5=Bjørn|first5=M.|last6=Ramløv|first6=H.|last7=Kristensen|first7=R. M.|date=2011-03-22|title=Survival in extreme environments - on the current knowledge of adaptations in tardigrades|url=https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1111/j.1748-1716.2011.02252.x|journal=Acta Physiologica|language=en|volume=202|issue=3|pages=409–420|doi=10.1111/j.1748-1716.2011.02252.x|issn=1748-1708}} Tardigrades are able to withstand such cold temperatures not by avoiding freezing using [[antifreeze protein]]s as a freeze avoidance organism would, but rather by tolerating ice formation in the extracellular body water, activated by ice nucleating proteins. In addition to other organisms, plants ([[Plant]]ae) can be either stenothermic or eurythermic. Plants inhabiting the [[Subarctic climate|boreal]] and [[Polar climate|polar]] climates generally tend to be cold-eurythermic, enduring temperatures as cold as –85°, and as warm as at least 20 °C, such as boreal deciduous conifers.{{Cite journal|last=Box|first=Elgene O.|date=1996|title=Plant Functional Types and Climate at the Global Scale|jstor=3236274|journal=Journal of Vegetation Science|volume=7|issue=3|pages=309–320|doi=10.2307/3236274}} This is in direct contrast to plants that typically inhabit more [[Tropics|tropical]] or [[Montane ecosystems|montane]] regions, where plants may have purely tolerable range between only about 10° and 25 °C, such as the [[Banyan|banyan tree]]. [[File:Common carp.jpg|alt=An illustration of the carp.|thumb|The common carp (''Cyprinus carpio'') has shown higher protein synthesis rates at high temperatures.]] == Eurythermal Protein Adaptation == The tolerance for extreme body temperatures in a given eurythermic organism is largely due to an increased temperature tolerance by the respective organism's homologous proteins. In particular, the proteins of a warm-adapted species may be inherently more eurythermal than a cold-adapted species, with warm-adapted species' proteins withstanding higher temperatures before beginning to [[Denaturation (biochemistry)|denature]], therefore avoiding possible cell death.{{Cite journal|last=Dietz|first=T. J.|last2=Somero|first2=G. N.|date=1992-04-15|title=The threshold induction temperature of the 90-kDa heat shock protein is subject to acclimatization in eurythermal goby fishes (genus Gillichthys).|url=http://www.pnas.org/cgi/doi/10.1073/pnas.89.8.3389|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|volume=89|issue=8|pages=3389–3393|doi=10.1073/pnas.89.8.3389|pmc=48873}} Eurythermal species also have shown adaptations in protein synthesis rates compared to non-eurythermal similar species. Rainbow trout''[[Rainbow trout|(Salmo gairdneri]]'') have shown constant protein synthesis rates \left(Q_{10}\right) over temperatures ranging from 5° to 20 °C, after acclimating to any temperature in this range for 1 month. In contrast, carp [[Common carp|(C''yprinus carpio'']]'')'' have shown significantly higher protein synthesis rates after acclimating to higher water temperatures (25 °C) than after acclimating to lower water temperatures (10 °C).{{Cite journal|last=Loughna|first=P. T.|last2=Goldspink|first2=G.|date=1985-09-01|title=Muscle Protein Synthesis Rates During Temperature Acclimation in a Eurythermal (Cyprinus Carpio) and a Stenothermal (Salmo Gairdneri) Species of Teleost|url=http://jeb.biologists.org/content/118/1/267|journal=Journal of Experimental Biology|language=en|volume=118|issue=1|pages=267–276|issn=0022-0949}} This type of experiment is common throughout fish. A similar example is given by the Senegalese sole (''[[Solea senegalensis]]''), which, when acclimated to temperatures of 26 °C, produced a significantly higher amount of [[taurine]], [[Glutamic acid|glutamate]], [[Gamma-Aminobutyric acid|GABA]] and [[glycine]] compared to acclimation to 12 °C. This may mean that the aforementioned compounds aid in antioxidant defense, osmoregulatory processes, or energetic purposes at these temperatures. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{Wiktionary-inline|eurytherm}} [[Category:Animal physiology]] [[Category:Ecology]]

revision.comment: Survival of the metal posts added
revision.text:
[[File:Fog House - geograph.org.uk - 101819.jpg|thumb|A Fog House at Invercauld near [[Braemar]]]] '''Fog Houses''' are a special type of pleasure or [[Summer house|summer]] house popular in Scotland and at one time commonly found on many country estates as a feature in the pleasure gardens.Walker, Page 64Buxbaum (1989), 152 The name 'Fog' derives from the [[Scots language|Scots]] word for the [[moss]] that was a major feature of the building, mainly used to line the walls and roof.[http://www.dsl.ac.uk/entry/snd/fog Dictionary of the Scots Language] ==Description== One definition states that 'Fog Houses' were 'Pleasure Houses', small shelters lined with mossy turf.[http://www.dsl.ac.uk/entry/snd/fog Dictionary of the Scots Language] They were often thatched with materials such as heather. Contents typically included a curved bench placed against the walls with other features such as the example at Bonnington Isle that had its table and bench neatly covered with moss,Buxbaum (1987), Page 17Walker, Page 64 and the one at Ballochmyle in Ayrshire that had the verses of a Robert Burns song hanging from the walls.Dougal, Page 163 [[File:Fog House on Bonnington Isle, River Clyde.JPG|thumb|Foundations of the Bonnington Isle Fog House.]] ==Examples of Fog Houses== *'''Ballochmyle Estate''' - Destroyed by fire by vandals in 1944, the Ballochmyle Fog House is said to have been built by Claude Alexander, the brother of [[Wilhelmina Alexander]], on the site of the where Robert Burns' first saw his 'Bonnie Lass o' Ballochmyle'.Boyle, Page 20Douglas, page 110 Other authors state that it was a nephew who built it.McIntyre, page 96 In surviving photographs the two support poles at the front of the building appear to be cut fir trees, however they were actually made of iron. The roof is thatched and the flimsy walls appear to be made of heather.[http://www.ayrshirehistory.com/mauchline_ballochmyle_estate.html The Fog House in the Ballochmyle Estate]Buxbaum (1989), Page 152 The OS maps show that it was located on one of the many woodland walks to the west of the stables. The Jacob's Ladders Steps gave access to it for visitors approaching from the direction of [[Catrine]]. The metal 'tree trunk' supports were rescued and now adorn a garden in the locality. Ballochmyle lies near [[Mauchline]] and Robert Burns' [[Gilbert Burns (farmer)|Mossgeil Farm]] where Robert lived for a time. Whilst walking in the private estate he saw [[Wilhelmina Alexander]], sister of the owner, walking alone and this inspired him to compose a romantic song. Burns wrote to her, enclosing the song, seeking her permission to allow him to publish it. Wilhelmina was 30 years old at the time and no great beauty, so thinking that Robert was teasing her and being aware of his reputation she never replied. The correspondence was however in later life one of her most prized possessions and, as stated, the Ballochmyle Fog House was built in honour of the occasion.[http://www.burnsmuseum.org.uk/collections/object_detail/3.6275.c Burns Museum]Mackay, Page 246 These verses were hung on the walls of the fog houseDougal, Page 163McIntyre, page 96 ''The Lass o'Ballochmyle'' {| border="0" |- |
:''Twas even-the dewy fields were green'', :''On every blade the pearls hang''; :''The zephyr wanton'd round the bean'', :''And bore its fragrant sweets alang'': :''In ev'ry glen the mavis sang'', :''All nature list'ning seem'd the while'', :''Except where greenwood echoes rang'', :''Amang the braes o' Ballochmyle''. |}
{| border="0" |- |
:''With careless step I onward strayed'', :''My heart rejoiced in Nature's joy'', :''When, musing in a lonely glade'', :''A maiden fair I chanced to spy''. :''Her look was like the morning's eye'', :''Her air like Nature's vernal smile''; :''Perfection whispered, passing by'', :''Behold the lass o' Ballochmyle!''.
|} Cuthbertson visited in the 1940s and comments on the winding mossy paths by which the 'heather house' was reached, confirming that it was built on the site where the poet first espied [[Wilhelmina Alexander]].Cuthbertson, page 101Douglas, page 110 He goes on to mention the rarely visited 'Poet's Seat', a vantage point where Burns would sit and think over his poems and songs. The seat was the branch of an oak that grew horizontally at this point.Cuthbertson, page 103 The building that overlooked Gaans Holm was octagonal and nine feet wide. It was originally open on three sides however it was later altered to have a doorway and two windows. It had symbols such as hearts and cupid's arrows in addition to the aforementioned verses.Hood, p.45 The board with the verses was stolen and only recovered twenty years later from an address in Glasgow.Mauchline in Times Past. p.36 Douglas refers to the fog house as a rustic grotto and states that the two verses were recorded on a tablet.Douglas, page 110 [[File:Fog house. - geograph.org.uk - 91762.jpg|thumb|Ruins of the old New Mar Lodge Fog House]] *'''Bonnington Estate''' - The cast iron bridge here is presumed to be that built for Lady Mary Ross who replaced or adapted the dovecot which stood on Bonnington Isle, to which the bridge leads, with a 'Fog House', lined with moss. The Wordsworths visited the site in 1803 and Dorothy Wordsworth described the interior of the fog house as being 'as snug as a bird's nest' and resembling a scooped out haystack.[https://canmore.org.uk/site/228186/bonnington-linn-foot-bridge Canmore RCAHMS] It had a domed roof and the walls, roof and furniture were neatly covered with moss. It reminded her of huts illustrated in the book of Captain Cook's Voyages.Buxbaum (1989), Page 151 The building had a lockable door and was reached as mentioned via a cast iron bridge that replaced an earlier wooden one. Dorothy was however far from impressed by the view from this fog house and saw it as being too close to the path frequented by visitors. She did however regard it as being the finest example of a fog house that she saw during her tour in Scotland.Walker, Page 64 The fog house here no longer exists although the stone foundations are still visible and the bridge, although still present, cannot be used. *'''Craufurdland Estate''' - A fog house is shown in the 1856 [[Ordnance Survey|OS]] map on the northern side of the Craufurdland Water close to Mount Tarbor however it is no longer marked in 1897. *'''Invercauld Estate''' - A fog house in 2010 was located above [[Invercauld Castle]] on a woodland walk overlooking the park. It is featured in the photograph above. *'''New Mar Lodge''' - locally known as [[Mar Lodge|Corriemulzie Cottage]], New Mar Lodge is situated near Linn of Corriemulzie at the top of Mar Lodge Brae. The Fog House is now a ruin with only the drystone walls surviving. *'''Penicuik Estate''' (NT 21728 58916) - In the 1990s a ruinous fog house was recorded on the Pencuik Estate.[https://canmore.org.uk/collection/1447224 RCAHMS Canmore] *'''Fullarton Estate''' - At the [[Crosbie Castle and the Fullarton estate|Fullarton Estate]] near [[Troon]] in South Ayrshire had thatched lodge called 'Heather House' that stood at the entrance to the house until it burned down in the 1950s. *'''Castle Semple''' - The old OS maps show that a Fog House once stood on Courtshaw Hill close to Lochwinnoch and the site of the old mansion house and its cascades feature. A [[Moot hill|moot hill]] was also once located here. ==References== {{Portal|Scotland}} ;Notes {{Reflist|colwidth=35em}} ;Sources * Buxbaum, Tim (1987). ''Scottish Doocots.'' Shire Publications. {{ISBN|978-0-85263-848-4}}. * Buxbaum, Tim (1989). ''Scottish Garden Buildings. From Food to Folly.'' Edinburgh : Mainstream Publishing. {{ISBN|1-85158-113-8}}. * Boyle, A. M. (1996). ''The Ayrshire Book of Burns-Lore''. Darvel : Alloway Publishing. {{ISBN|0-907526-71-3}}. * Cuthbertson, D. C. ''Autumn in Kyle'. London : Herbert Jenkins. * Dougal, Charles S. (1911). ''The Burns Country''. London: A & C Black. * Douglas, William Scott (Edit.) (1938). ''The Kilmarnock Edition of the Poetical Works of Robert Burns''. Glasgow : The Scottish Daily Express. * Hood, John (2001). ''Old Mauchline and Tarbolton''. Catrine : Stenlake Publishing. {{ISBN|1-84033-172-0}}. * Mackay, James (2004). ''Burns. A Biography of Robert Burns''. Darvel : Alloway Publishing. {{ISBN|978-0-907526-85-8}} * McIntyre, Ian (2001). Robert Burns. A Life. New York : Welcome Rain Publishers. {{ISBN|1-56649-205-X}}. * ''Mauchline in Times Past''. Mauchline Burns Club. A Countryside Publication. {{ISBN|0-86157-205-X}}. * Walker, Carol Kyros ed. (1997). ''Recollections of a Tour Made in Scotland by Dorothy Wordsworth''. Yale University Press. {{ISBN|0-300-07155-8}}. ==External links== {{commons category|Fog houses}} *[http://www.ayrshirehistory.com/mauchline_ballochmyle_estate.html The Fog House in the Ballochmyle Estate] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tRtNojVbPjQ Video footage of the Braes of Ballochmyle] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=e-_-2Fo9Mgc Video footage of the Jacob's Ladder site, Fog House, etc.] [[Category:Summer]] [[Category:Robert Burns]] [[Category:Folly buildings in Scotland]]

page.title: Gasoline and diesel usage and pricing

revision.text:
{{update|date=October 2018}} {{confusing|date=May 2016}} [[Image:Fan-Tankstelle von Dynamo Dresden.JPG|thumb|160px|Example from Germany 2007, 1.319 €/L=US$7.65/gal]]
The usage and pricing of gasoline (or ''petrol'') results from factors such as [[petroleum|crude oil]] prices, processing and distribution costs, local demand, the strength of local currencies, local taxation, and the availability of local sources of gasoline (supply). Since fuels are traded worldwide, the trade prices are similar. The price paid by consumers largely reflects national pricing policy. Some regions, such as Europe and Japan, impose high [[fuel tax|taxes]] on gasoline (petrol); others, such as [[Saudi Arabia]] and [[Venezuela]], subsidize the cost.<ref name="gtz2010">{{cite web|title=International Fuel Prices 2010/11|author=Deutsche Gesellschaft für Internationale Zusammenarbeit (German Agency for International Cooperation)|url=http://www.giz.de/Themen/en/dokumente/giz-en-IFP2010.pdf|format=PDF|accessdate=27 March 2013}}</ref> Western countries have among the highest usage rates per person. The largest consumer is the United States, which used an average of 368 million [[US liquid gallon#Liquid volume|US gallons]] (1.46 [[gigalitre]]s) each day in 2011.<ref name=key>[http://www.nacsonline.com/NACS/Resources/campaigns/GasPrices_2012/Pages/StatisticsDefinitions.aspx Fueling America: A Snapshot of Key Facts and Figures] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120608055828/http://www.nacsonline.com/NACS/Resources/campaigns/GasPrices_2012/Pages/StatisticsDefinitions.aspx |date=2012-06-08 }} Retrieved 7 August 2012</ref>
==Fuel prices in the United States==
[[File:US gas prices July 2012.png|thumb|Percentage of cost for gasoline and diesel in the United States.]] In 2008 a report by [[Cambridge Energy Research Associates]] stated that 2007 had been the year of peak gasoline usage in the United States, and that record energy prices would cause an "enduring shift" in energy consumption practices.<ref> {{cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB121392646391690835?mod=googlenews_wsj |title=Prices Curtail US Gasoline Use |publisher=[[Wall Street Journal]] |date=20 June 2008 |page=A4 |author=Ana Campoy }}</ref> According to the report, in April fuel consumption had been lower than a year before for the sixth straight month, suggesting 2008 would be the first year US usage declined in 17 years. The total annual distance driven in the US began declining in 2006.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/06/19/business/19gas.html?ref=business |title=Driving Less, Americans Finally React to Sting of Gas Prices, a Study Says |publisher=[[New York Times]] |date=19 June 2008 |author=Clifford Krauss |accessdate=6 January 2013}}</ref>
The average price per US gallon in 2012 ({{as of|2012|12|31|lc=y}}) was $3.618 (96¢/L), the highest ever for a year. {{As of|2012|12|31}}, the average price of gasoline was $3.298/gal (87¢/L),{{contradiction inline |reason=Two different "average prices" given for the same date in the region |date=May 2014}} with New York at $3.70/gal (98¢/L) for the highest in the US, and [[Colorado]] at $2.987/gal (79¢/L) for the lowest.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eia.gov/dnav/pet/pet_pri_gnd_a_epmr_pte_dpgal_w.htm |publisher=US EIA |title=Weekly Retail Gasoline and Diesel Prices |accessdate=6 January 2013}}</ref>
Finished motor gasoline amounts to 44% of the total US consumption of petroleum products.<ref>{{cite web |title=US Product Supplied for Crude Oil and Petroleum Products |author=US Energy Information Administration |accessdate=25 May 2007|url=http://tonto.eia.doe.gov/dnav/pet/pet_cons_psup_dc_nus_mbblpd_a.htm}}</ref> This corresponds to 18.5 [[exajoules]] per year. {{As of|2012}}, the cost of crude oil accounted for 62% of the cost of a gallon of gasoline in the United State while refining accounted for just 12%. Taxes and distribution/marketing accounted for 12% and 14% respectively.<ref>[http://www.eia.gov/tools/faqs/faq.cfm?id=22&t=10 What do I pay for in a gallon of regular gasoline?] US Energy Information Administration. Retrieved 7 August 2012.</ref>
After [[Hurricane Katrina]] and [[Hurricane Rita]], gas prices started rising. They became record high levels. In terms of the aggregate economy, increases in crude oil prices significantly predict the growth of real gross domestic product (GDP), but increases in natural gas prices do not.<ref name="Kliesen, Kevin L 2006">Kliesen, Kevin L. "Rising Natural Gas Prices And Real Economic Activity". Review (00149187) 88.6 (2006): 511-526. Academic Search Premier. Web. 12 February 2013</ref> After the damages from the hurricanes ran up gas prices. By 30 August, a day after Katrina’s landfall, prices in the spot market, which typically include a premium above the wellhead price, had surged past $11 per gigajoule ($12 per million British thermal units), and on 22 September 2005, the day before Rita’s landfall, the spot price had risen to $14/GJ ($15 per million BTU).<ref name="Kliesen, Kevin L 2006"/>
In the fifteen years prior to the [[1973 oil crisis]], gasoline prices in the U.S. had lagged well behind inflation.<ref name=gpcutinf>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=1t1VAAAAIBAJ&sjid=A9gDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4393%2C4881980 |work=Eugene Register-Guard |location=(Oregon)|agency=Associated Press |title=Gas prices catch up to inflation |date=February 24, 1974 |page=6A}}</ref>
=== Crude oil === [[File:Oil_prices_to_gas_prices_graph.png|500px|thumb|right|[[West Texas Intermediate|Crude oil]] prices to gas prices]] [[Crude oil]] is the greatest contributing factor when it comes to the price of gasoline. This includes the resources it takes for exploration, to remove it from the ground, and transport it. Between 2004 and 2008, there was an increase in fuel costs due in large part to a worldwide increase in demand for crude oil. Prices leapt from {{convert|35|to|140|$/oilbbl|$/m3}}, causing a corresponding increase in gas prices.<ref>Rittenberg and Tregarthen. [http://www.saylor.org/site/wp-content/uploads/2012/06/ECON101-2.4.4.pdf Principles of Microeconomics]: Chapter 4. Retrieved 19 June 2012.</ref> On the supply side, [[OPEC]] (or the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries) has a great deal to do with the price of gasoline, both in the United States and around the world. The speculation of oil commodities can also affect the gasoline market.
=== Taxes === {{main article|Fuel taxes in the United States}} Taxes are the next biggest contributor to gasoline prices at around 12%. In the United States, both state and federal taxes apply to gasoline. In addition, other taxes may be placed on gas including applicable state sales taxes, gross receipts taxes, oil inspection fees, underground storage tank fees and other miscellaneous environmental fees.
=== Marketing and distribution ===
Distribution and marketing makes up the remaining 5%. The price of transporting crude oil to a refinery then gasoline to a point of distribution is passed on to the consumer. In addition the price to market the fuel brand is passed on.
=== Other factors ===
Aside from this breakdown, many other factors affect gasoline prices. Extreme weather, war or natural disaster in areas where oil is produced can also in turn raise the price of a gallon of gasoline. Legislation by several states for cleaner burning fuel also affects certain areas' prices of gasoline.
Balance between [[Supply (economics)|supply]] and [[demand]] directly affects the price of gasoline. U.S. consumption of gasoline follows a seasonal pattern, where every year it is more expensive during the summer months when more people are driving. The long-term trend of consumption has been to increase year over year since 1950, with dips around the introduction of [[corporate average fuel economy]] standards and the [[1979 energy crisis]], the [[early 1990s recession]] and [[Gulf War]], and the [[Great Depression]].<ref>[https://www.npr.org/2016/09/02/492271953/u-s-gasoline-use-hits-a-record-but-that-may-not-last U.S. Gasoline Use Hits A Record, But That May Not Last] (with chart)</ref>
==Petrol usage and pricing in Europe== [[Image:Benzinpreis ch monatlich.png|thumb|250px|Gasoline and Diesel nominal price development 1993-2014 in Switzerland (CHF/l).]] Most European countries have high [[fuel tax]]es. The prices have traditionally been three to four times the price in the United States, with prices during 2000–2005 of €1.00/litre<ref>[[:File:Benzinpreis.png]]</ref> (about US$1.42/L or $5.40/US gallon) while the US had prices around $1.50/gal or $0.40/L. After a large increase until the summer of 2008, the end of 2008 experienced a strong decline linked with a sharp economic downturn, with the average price of fuel in the US at $1.613/gal (29 December 2008). However, the price of fuel in Europe is still more than double the US price at $1.85/litre.<ref>[http://www.benzin.sk/obr/europske_priemerne_ceny_2008-11-17_benzin_sdanou.jpg "European Prices in Chart"]</ref> [[Russia]] and some neighboring countries have a much smaller tax, with fuel prices similar to the US.<ref name="gtz2010"/>
Competitive petrol pricing in the UK is led by supermarkets with their own forecourts. Generally each supermarket tends to match the other's prices; the lead players being [[Asda]], [[Tesco]], [[Sainsbury's]] and [[Morrisons]]. In recent years the [[The Automobile Association|AA]] has criticized the speculators as being the prime reason for fuel fluctuations in the UK.<ref>{{cite news|last=Deo|first=Ritwik|title=Petrol prices on the slide|url=http://www.myfamilyclub.co.uk/news/petrol-prices-on-the-slide-what-does-it-mean-for-you-27325|newspaper=My Family Club|date=October 2012}}</ref>
==Countries with subsidised gasoline== A number of countries subsidize the cost of petrol/gasoline and other petroleum products. Subsidies make transport of people and goods cheaper, but discourage fuel efficiency. In some countries, the soaring cost of crude oil since 2003 has led to these subsidies being cut, moving inflation from the government debt to the general populace, sometimes resulting in political unrest.
Fuel subsidies are common in oil-rich nations. Countries with subsidized fuel include [[United States of America]], [[Saudi Arabia]], [[Iran]], [[Egypt]], [[Burma]], [[Kuwait]], [[Bahrain]], [[Trinidad and Tobago]], [[Brunei]] and [[Bolivia]].
In February 2010, the Iranian government implemented an energy price reform by which the energy subsidies were to be removed in five years; the most important price hike was in gasoline, as the price went up from 100 rials ($0.10 US) to 400 rials ($0.40 US) per litre, with a ration of 100 litres per month for private passenger cars (later reduced to 60 litres per month).
On 26 December 2010, the Bolivian government issued a decree removing subsidies which had fixed petrol/gasoline and diesel prices for the past seven years. Arguing that illegal exports (contraband) of gasoline and diesel fuel to neighboring countries by individuals for personal profit was harming the economy, Bolivia eliminated the subsidies and raised gasoline prices as much as 83%. After widespread labor strikes, the Bolivian government canceled all future planned price hikes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gtz.de/de/dokumente/giz2011-fuel-price-reform-bolivia-december-2010.pdf|title=Fuel Price Reform in Bolivia|publisher=Deutsche Gesellschaft für Internationale Zusammenarbeit (GIZ)}}</ref>
Venezuela used to have the cheapest gasoline in the world for decades, however on 19 February 2016 president Nicolás Maduro used decree powers to raise fuel prices by 6000%. This was the first rise in petrol prices in 20 years and he also set in place a sharp devaluation of the currency which he said aimed to shore up the country's failing economy, hard hit by falling oil prices which make up 95% of foreign income. Prices at the pump in Venezuela jumped as much as 6,086% for 95 octane gasoline, from 0.097 bolivars to 6 bolivars.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/feb/18/venezuela-president-raises-fuel-price-by-1300-and-devalues-bolivar-to-tackle-crisis|title=Venezuela president raises fuel price by 6,000% and devalues bolivar to tackle crisis|first=Sibylla|last=Brodzinsky|date=17 February 2016|publisher=|via=The Guardian}}</ref>
===Iran=== {{See also|Smuggling in Iran|2007 Gasoline Rationing Plan in Iran}} The Iranian government introduced [[Iranian subsidy reform plan|an energy price reform]] in February 2010. The reform was brought forward by the government and approved with some changes by the parliament. The major aim of the policy was to slow down the increasing trend of energy consumption in Iran by removing the energy subsidies. The plan included electricity, natural gas, gasoline, and diesel subsidies. According to the plan, all energy prices were to increase by 20 percent annually. The price reform was particularly important in gasoline, as consumption had been increasing dramatically creating a huge burden on government budget. Furthermore, to meet demand, Iran had to import gasoline from other countries, which made the country vulnerable to possible sanctions by the US and European countries. The gas price prior to reform was $0.10 US per liter with the quota of 100 liters per month per passenger car. The reform raised the price to $0.40 US per liter and later reduced the ration to 60 liters per month. The price for over-quota consumption and the imported cars were $0.70 US per liter. The energy price reform included a cash-rebate program through which each person received 455,000 rials ($15 US) per month from the government. The overall consumption of gasoline after the reform decreased from about 65 million liters per day to about 54 million liters per day.<ref>[[Iranian targeted subsidy plan]].</ref>
The price of gasoline based on the official USD to IRR rate is 0.29 USD/Litre in 2018 which is the second cheapest price in the world after Venezuela. <ref>https://www.globalpetrolprices.com/gasoline_prices/</ref>
===Nigeria=== On 1 January 2012, the Nigerian government headed by president Goodluck Ebele Jonathan, tried to cease the subsidy on petrol and deregulate the oil prices by announcing the new price for petrol as USD 0.88/litre from the old subsidised price of USD 0.406/litre (LAGOS), which in areas distant from Lagos petrol was priced at USD 1.25/litre. This led to the longest general strike (eight days), riots, Arab spring like protests and on 16 January 2012 the government capitulated by announcing a new price of USD 0.60/litre with an envisaged price of USD 2.0/litre in distant areas.<ref>https://www.economist.com/news/middle-east-and-africa/21699171-petrol-prices-are-now-bit-more-realistic-will-naira-be-next-fuel-and</ref> In May 2016 the Buhari administration increased fuel prices again to NGN 145 per litre ($0.43 at black market rates for the currency).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-16382286|title=Nigeria fury as fuel prices double after subsidy ends|date=2 January 2012|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk}}</ref>
===Mexico=== PEMEX, a government company in charge of selling oil in Mexico is subsidized by the Mexican government. This serves to quell inflationary pressures in Mexico. Mexico buys much of its gasoline and diesel from the United States and resells it at US$98 per barrel. Many residents of US border communities cross the border to buy fuel in Mexico,<ref>http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/mexico/tijuana/20081127-9999-1b27gas.html</ref> thereby enjoying a cheaper fuel subsidy at the expense of Mexican taxpayers. This has caused frequent supply shortages at a number of filling stations along the border for Mexican drivers, especially truck and bus drivers who use diesel.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/public/article/SB121426584632198453-_wjnmFYCNcbM6jFvYcx2zPf03Xs_20080723.html|title=Fill 'er Up: Gas Is Cheap in Tijuana, So Californians Buy Big Fuel Tanks|publisher=The Wall Street Journal|author1=JOEL MILLMAN|author2=ANA CAMPOY|date=24 June 2008|p=A1}}</ref>
In 2017, Mexico ended its oil industry subsidies, leading to increased prices and [[2017 Mexican protests|widespread protests]] throughout the country.<ref name="NewYorker">{{cite web|last1=Okeowo|first1=Alexis|title=The Gas-Price Protests Gripping Mexico|url=https://www.newyorker.com/news/daily-comment/the-gas-price-protests-gripping-mexico|website=[[The New Yorker]]|accessdate=14 February 2018|date=24 January 2017|language=en}}</ref>
===Trinidad and Tobago=== Trinidad and Tobago through its national energy agencies [[Petrotrin]] and Trinidad and Tobago National Petroleum Marketing Company Limited (NP)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.np.co.tt/about-us/company-profile/|title=Company Profile - NP|publisher=}}</ref> offers petroleum fuels at varying subsidised prices to the users within the country.<ref>http://www.energy.tt/index.php?categoryid=355&p2001_articleid=1233</ref> Unleaded Gasoline is offered at two grades - Ron 91 at US$0.43/Litre and Ron 95 at US$0.91/Litre. Diesel is offered at US$0.24/Litre making this fuel some of the cheapest in the world.
There are an estimated 791,086 cars in the country as at February 2015 and they consume 1.2 billion litres of liquid fuel annually The Government of Trinidad and Tobago spent an estimated US$173.2 million in subsidies for gasoline and diesel in half year period October 2014 - March 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guardian.co.tt/business/2015-05-11/fuel-subsidy-lower-912m|title=Fuel subsidy lower at $912m|publisher=}}</ref>
===United States=== [[Energy subsidies|The oil industry receives subsidies]] through the United States tax code, which include Percentage Depletion Allowance,<ref>https://www.wsj.com/articles/does-the-oil-and-gas-industry-still-need-tax-breaks-1479092522 </ref> Domestic Manufacturing Tax Deduction, the Foreign Tax Credit and Expensing Intangible Drilling Costs. It is estimated that these tax deductions are worth $4 billion annually and are currently being debated by the government for reform.{{citation needed|date=September 2013}} Although such subsidies exist, the sale of fuel is also taxed at rates that far exceed the sales tax rates for other goods, to help pay for bridge and road repair. It is thus unclear whether the tax impact on fuel is a net subsidy or not.
===Venezuela=== Today, [[PDVSA]], Venezuelan state-owned company, spends US$1.7 billion in direct costs of importation of gasoline, and subsidizes all sales of gasoline in the internal Venezuelan market. The sale price of gasoline is US$0.015{{update inline|reason=Venezuelan currency loses about half its value every month so this figure needs to be updated every week.|date=December 2017}} per liter, on a fixed price in the local currency that has been in effect since 1997. Given the low price of gasoline, it is distributed free of charge to gas stations.<ref>http://www.abc.es/internacional/20130515/abci-venezuela-gasolina-201305142039.html Venezuela is going bankrupt for having the cheapest gasoline in the world (ABC Spain - in Spanish)</ref>
==Countries which had formerly subsidised gasoline==
===Indonesia=== In March 2005, [[Indonesia]] increased the price of gasoline and diesel by 29%, causing widespread protests. The price of gasoline was raised from [[Indonesian rupiah|Rp]] (US$0.20) per litre to Rp 2,400 (US$0.25) per litre, while diesel rose from Rp 1,650 (US$0.18) to Rp 2,100 (US$0.23). Prices were increased again in October to Rp (US$0.48) a litre, for gasoline, while diesel was increased to Rp 4,300 (US$0.46), and [[kerosene]], used for cooking, increased from Rp 700 (US$0.08) to Rp 2,000 (US$0.22) per litre. The price increases came as oil prices threatened to increase the government's oil subsidy to US$14 billion per year, and caused further protests.
With oil reaching over US$145 a barrel, Indonesia further increased prices on 24 May 2008 to Rp 6,000 (approx. US$0.65) per litre, and diesel to Rp 5,500 (approx. US$0.60) per litre, while kerosene was raised to Rp 2,500 (approx. US$0.28), moves which caused widespread protests.<ref>[http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5jtG3zfKzch9BNr7LEMc70IkR5qsg AFP: Indonesian police, protesters clash over fuel price hike: reports<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> In addition, it was suggested that private car owners, who are wealthy in Indonesian terms, would eventually be excluded from subsidies entirely, with the cheap fuel limited to public transport and motorcycles.
In June 2013, the government raised the price of low-octane gasoline 44% to 6,500 rupiah ($0.66) per liter and of diesel 22% to 5,500 rupiah per liter to help close a widening budget deficit. The move caused violent protest in some areas.
Furthermore, in November 18, 2014, the new government led by President [[Joko Widodo]] reallocated the government subsidy for gasoline and diesel into nation's infrastructure, education and health budget, hence raised the price of subsidized gasoline and diesel by Rp 2,000 each, so the price of gasoline and diesel became Rp 8,500 and Rp 7,500 respectively. This decision created inflation and protest throughout the archipelago.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2014-11-21/indonesian-rupiah-heads-for-weekly-gain-after-fuel-subsidies-cut.html | work=Bloomberg | first=Andrew | last=Janes | title=Indonesian Rupiah Completes Weekly Gain After Fuel Subsidies Cut | date=21 November 2014}}</ref>
People have been encouraged to switch to [[Liquefied petroleum gas|LPG]] for cooking, as Indonesia is the world's largest exporter, whereas its oil industry is in decline, and it is now a net importer.
===Malaysia=== [[Malaysia]] had been subsidising gasoline since 1983<ref>http://www.iisd.org/gsi/sites/default/files/ffs_malaysia_czguide.pdf</ref> and recently had been spending US$6.7 billion on subsidising gasoline, diesel and gas each year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/malaysia-axes-fuel-subsidies-oil-prices-drop-27075677|title=International News: Latest Headlines, Video and Photographs from Around the World -- People, Places, Crisis, Conflict, Culture, Change, Analysis and Trends|first=ABC|last=News|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |author=AP |title=Malaysia to lift fuel price controls |date={{date|2008-06-03}}| work=Associated Press For Petrol price : old price = rm$1.92/litre (US$0.59/litre or US$2.22/Gallon) increase to new price rm$270.00/litre (US$0.83/litre = US$3.12/Gallon, base on US$1 = MYR$3.27); For Diesel price : old price = MYR$1.58/litre (US$0.48/litre or US$1.83/Gallon) increase to new price MYR$2.58/litre (US$0.79/litre = US$2.98/Gallon, base on US$1 =MYR$3.27); |accessdate={{date|2008-07-20}}}}</ref> On 5 June 2008 gasoline prices increased by 40% to [[MYR]]2.70/litre (US$3.30 a gallon), from MYR1.92/litre (US$2.32 a gallon). Diesel prices rose by MYR1.00/litre to MYR2.58 (US$3.04 per gallon), a 63% increase. It was announced that price increases were planned to bring fuel prices in line with global market cost, suggesting that it may hit US$3.80 per gallon by August. The Malaysian government has also announced a one-off cash rebate of MYR625 per year to Malaysian citizens who own cars with an engine capacity of 3,000 cc or less and MYR200 tax rebate to cars with an engine capacity of 3,000 cc and above to offset the increased costs.<ref>{{cite news |author=AP |title=Malaysia considers cash handouts as fuel hike looms |date={{date|2008-06-04}}| url=http://money.cnn.com/2008/06/04/news/international/gas_subsidies.ap/index.htm | work=Associated Press |accessdate={{date|2008-06-04}}}}</ref> The government introduced a temporary ban on buying fuel within 50 km of the country border, but the ban was suspended following a price increase on 7 June 2008 for petrol of 41% (to [[MYR]]2.70 a litre) and for diesel of 63% (to [[MYR]]2.58).<ref>{{cite news |author=Reuters |title=Malaysia lifts ban on fuel sales to foreigners |date={{date|2008-06-05}}| url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/oilRpt/idUKKLR46220080605 | work=Reuters UK |accessdate={{date|2008-06-05}}}}</ref>
On 22 June 2008, the Malaysian government announced plans to set up separate pumps at its border petrol stations to sell fuel to foreigners at market rates so that only locals can benefit from subsidised petrol. The new pumps will target Singaporeans and Thais who make day trips across the border to fill their tanks with cheaper fuel there, although Singapore-registered cars must have their tanks at least three-quarters full before they will be permitted to leave Singapore in any case. Petrol stations within {{convert|50|km|mi|abbr=on}} of the country's northern border with Thailand or southern border with Singapore would be affected.<ref>{{cite news |author=Channel Newsasia |title=Malaysia to set up separate border petrol pumps for foreigners |date={{date|2008-06-22}}|url= http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/afp_asiapacific/view/355701/1/.html | work=Channel Newsasia |accessdate={{date|2008-06-22}}}}</ref> Recently, the fuel price has dropped to MYR 2.45 and it has dropped for the second time. A further reduction was made on 1 November 2008. RON97 petrol was reduced from MYR2.30 per litre (MYR8.7/US gal) to MYR2.15 a litre, RON92 petrol from MYR2.20 to MYR2.05 a litre (MYR8.3/US gal to MYR7.8/US gal), and diesel from MYR2.20 to MYR2.05 per litre The Government revealed that it had ceased subsidizing petrol as of 1 November 2008 when the price of oil dipped below US$65 per barrel. However subsidies were still being paid for diesel and natural gas.<ref>{{cite news |author=Malaysian Insider|title= Malaysians are now paying petrol tax |date={{date|2008-11-18}}| url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/index.php/malaysia/12622-malaysians-are-now-paying-petrol-tax- | work=Malaysian Insider |accessdate={{date|2008-11-18}}}}</ref>
On 18 November 2008, the Malaysian government made further reductions in the price of gasoline cut pump prices by seven per cent to MYR2.00 ringgit per litre and diesel by 15 sen to MYR1.90 per litre. The government said that at current prices they were making about 30 sen per litre in sales. Then again on 3 December, petrol prices were reduced further. Gasoline prices were reduced 10 sen to MYR 1.90 per litre and as for diesel, they were reduced 10 sen to MYR 1.80 per litre.<ref>{{cite news |work=The Straits Times|title= M'sia to dump petrol subsidy? |date={{date|2008-11-19}}| url=http://www.straitstimes.com/Breaking%2BNews/SE%2BAsia/Story/STIStory_303779.html |accessdate={{date|2008-11-19}}}}</ref> On 16 December 2008 the price of RON97 petrol was reduced further to MYR1.80, while RON92 is selling at MYR1.70 per litre (MYR6.4/US gal). The pump price of diesel was also reduced to MYR1.70 a litre.<ref>{{cite news |title= Petrol and diesel down 10 sen |date={{date|2008-12-16}}| url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2008/12/16/nation/2815077&sec=nation |accessdate={{date|2008-12-16}}}}</ref>
From 1 September 2009 however, the price for RON97 increased to MYR2.05, while RON92 has been discontinued and replaced with RON95, at a price of MYR1.80.<ref>{{cite news |title= RON95 price up 5 sen to MYR1.80 |date={{date|2009-09-01}}| url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2009/9/1/nation/4625659&sec=nation |accessdate={{date|2009-09-01}}}}</ref> On 16 July 2010, petrol prices across the board was raised by 5 sen, which brought the prices of RON95, RON97 and diesel to MYR1.85, MYR2.10 and MYR1.75 per litre respectively. Since then, RON97 floats with government controlled revision reflecting the global crude oil prices. {{As of|2010|8|1}} only Malaysian-registered petrol vehicles may purchase RON95 fuel; foreign-registered vehicles (mainly from Singapore and Thailand) by law can only purchase RON97 (or diesel) at Malaysian service stations.
On 1 April 2011, RON97 increased from MYR2.50 to MYR2.70. In May 2011, RON97 further increased to MYR2.90, another record high for RON97 in Malaysia. A drop of MYR0.10 in June 2011 brings it to MYR2.80 per litre, the first price reduction since RON97 was floated at market rates.
On 3 September 2013, the price for RON 95 increased from MYR1.90 to MYR2.10, RON97 from MYR2.70 to MYR2.85, and diesel from MYR1.80 to MYR2.00.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/News/Nation/2013/09/04/ron-97-price-hike.aspx|title=RON 97 petrol to cost 15 sen more per litre - Nation - The Star Online|first=Nicholas|last=Cheng|publisher=}}</ref><ref>http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/impact-of-fuel-price-hike-on-consumers-will-be-widespread-warns-fomca</ref> This was further increased on 2 October 2014, whereby RON 95 would cost MYR2.30 and diesel would cost MYR2.20 per litre.<ref>http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/petrol-diesel-prices-up-by-20-sen-from-midnight</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.themalaymailonline.com/malaysia/article/fuel-prices-at-pumps-up-after-midnight|title=Fuel prices at pumps up after midnight|date=1 October 2014|publisher=}}</ref> Starting on 1 December 2014, Malaysia abolished fuel subsidies and began using a managed float system, in order to control the country's large current account deficit.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/business-30140728|title=Malaysia to end petrol and diesel subsidies|date=21 November 2014|publisher=|via=www.bbc.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/category/nation/2014/11/21/putrajaya-scraps-subsidies-for-ron95-diesel/|title=Putrajaya scraps subsidies for RON95, diesel|date=21 November 2014|publisher=}}</ref>
==Typical gasoline prices around the world== See [[fuel tax]] for tax information by country.
The [[Deutsche Gesellschaft für Internationale Zusammenarbeit]] (German Agency for International Cooperation) (GIZ) has published a list of worldwide gasoline prices by country every year since 1991. The results for 2010/2011 can be seen in [http://www.giz.de/Themen/en/dokumente/giz-en-IFP2010.pdf this document]. [http://www.reisen-tcs.ch/etc/medialib/travel/reiseinfos/pdf.Par.0014.File.tmp/EUR_essence.pdf Two week updates] for European countries can be consulted at the website of the Touring Club Switzerland.
Up to date prices for gasoline (unleaded) are available at http://www.globalpetrolprices.com/gasoline_prices/

== Protests ==
=== India === Wide protests on petrol price hikes have been frequent in the last 4–5 years. On 24 May 2012 the petrol price was hiked by [[Indian rupee|₹]]7.50, resulting prices in the range of ₹73 - 82 all over the country.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/business-news/WorldEconomy/Petrol-price-hiked-by-Rs-7-50-oil-firms-say-can-t-help-it/Article1-860185.aspx|title=Petrol price hiked by Rs. 7.50, oil firms say can't help it|newspaper=[[Hindustan Times]]|author=Agencies|date=24 May 2012|accessdate=24 May 2012}}</ref> Opposition had declared a [[bandh]] on 31 May 2012 across the country to protest against the price hike,<ref>{{cite news|title=Petrol price hike: Opposition unites to call for all India bandh on May 31 |url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2012-05-24/india/31838402_1_price-hike-bharat-bandh-petrol|accessdate=24 May 2012 | work=The Times Of India|date=24 May 2012}}</ref> which evoked mixed response, amid incidents of stone pelting, arson and road blockades in some parts of the country.<ref>{{cite news|title=Bharat bandh: Mixed response to nationwide strike against petrol price hike|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2012-05-31/india/31920392_1_mixed-response-bandh-supporters-shops-and-business-establishments|accessdate=31 May 2012|newspaper=[[The Times of India]]|date=31 May 2012|author=[[Press Trust of India]]|location=New Delhi, India}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Bharat Bandh: Nationwide protests on petrol price hike evoke mixed response|url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/india/bharat-bandh-nationwide-protests-on-petrol-price-hike-evoke-mixed-response-220487?pfrom=home-lateststories|accessdate=31 May 2012|newspaper=[[NDTV]]|date=31 May 2012|author=NDTV Correspondent|location=New Delhi, India}}</ref>
